Today it´s Denmark´s Liberation Day! 
The notice of the Germans had surrendered came May 4th, 1945 in the evening. But the German capitulation came into force on May 5th at eight o'clock in the morning.

Today you will see many Danes place candles in their windows.
 The reason for this is that Denmark in 1945 was liberated from 5 years of German occupation. 20.30 on May 4th, the announcement about the liberation was made on BBC shortwave radio from London. Although it had first official action the following day, everybody lit candles in their windows and rushed out on the streets to celebrate.

You will meet about 4000 international students at the University of Copenhagen. We have asked some of them about their reasons for coming to UCPH in the first place, and about how they like it now – and if they would share some of their own photos from life on campus. 

Here is what Helle from Norway writes:

Why did you choose to study at the University of Copenhagen?

In Norway, we are very fascinated about Denmark, and Copenhagen especially. It attracts us somehow, Norwegians just love Denmark. My father was born in Denmark, so I was curious to learn more about this happy, relaxed and creative country. I remember thinking about how it would be like to live and study in Copenhagen, and I remember sitting on my room googling the University. I read some personal stories and experiences from previous students, and got immediately convinced that this could be it. This could be my future! 

Where is your favourite spot on campus?

Konsistorialgården is the place at campus that gives me the best and warmest feeling inside. I have participated in annual summer parties with my faculty there some years in a row, and it is a place with so much history. It is fascinating to think about and try to imagine all the crazy, weird, funny and beautiful things that have happened in that yard throughout the years. The start of new friendships, people dancing and earlier generations of students falling in love, to mention a few of the good ones. 

Which of the courses you follow is your favourite and why?

I think European Pharmaceutical law, IPR & the Life Sciences was an amazing course. What you learn is so useful, and you end up reading and looking for supplementary literature in your spare time not because you want to do well on you exam, but because you personally want to learn more about a certain subject. That hasn't happened a lot for me. UNCPH should be so proud to be cooperating with the greatly talented and very emphatic Timo Minssen. He is by far my favourite lecturer at UNCPH. He was gone last year, lecturing at Oxford I think, but I hear that he is back now. Lucky for the University!   

Where are your favourite Christmas lights in Copenhagen?

I will have to get back to you on this one. Honestly I have been mostly inside reading lately. I like the lightning and decoration outside Frederikberg have (main entrance), but I could imagine you would like me to mention a place on campus.

You will meet about 4000 international students at the University of Copenhagen. We have asked some of them about their reasons for coming in the first place, and about how they like it now – and if they would share some of their own photos from life on campus. 
Here is what Klaudia from Poland writes:

Why did you choose to study at the University of Copenhagen?

I chose to study at the University of Copenhagen because I was attracted to the research profile of University, especially in pharmaceutical sciences fields. I like a lot offered study line in the pharmacy, chance to choose you own courses and the ability to cooperate with companies.

Where is your favourite spot on campus?

The pharmacy campus is not the newest one :) My favourite spot there is a roof of the building, where you can have a great view for Copenhagen.
Other nice spots: Biological gardens and Black Diamond for studying and entertainment. 

Which of the courses you follow is your favourite and why?

I am kind of nerdy type person and I love science especially one involving drugs discovery and development. Therefore my favourite courses are: Molecular Pharmacology and In vitro techniques in Biochemistry and Pharmacology. I choose to take these courses because they are involving mostly laboratory exercises with focus of my field of interests. In addition they are organized by dynamic and ambitious research group.

AS IN NATURE
The Sculptor Mogens Bøggild
21 March – 1 September 2013

Mogens Bøggild (1901-1987) was the greatest naturalist sculptor in Denmark in the 20th century. With sketches and models for major public monuments such as the Radio Sculpture in front of Radiohuset, the Danish “Broadcasting House”, in Rosenørns Allé and the Ceres Fountain in front of the town hall in Aarhus, Thorvaldsens Museum is for the first time mounting an exhibition focused on the works of Bøggild that are on show in public places.

Opening hours
